node.title: Generating 1D lower dimensional block and adding it to 3D filemesh
node.bodyText:
Hi :)
I was wondering if there is a way with the existing MeshGenerators to generate a lower dimensional block from a list of points (x,y,z) that describe a polyline and add this to an existing 3D filemesh. The polyline in my case is also following the edges of the filemesh.
My question is similar to this one #24174
But my filemesh (exodus format) is not coming from GMSH.
If this isnt possible does someone know a way/tool to do this?
Cheers
Florian

Hello
I m not sure we have tried to do this before but on paper it's possible.
Use a FileMeshGenerator to load your mesh
Use a ParsedCurveGenerator to create the 1D line (for example)
then you can either combine (detached meshes) using a CombineMeshGenerator or stitch them (you ll need a nodeset to stitch the polyline to on the multiD mesh)
Guillaume

Ah I see! Thanks a lot! ... maybe this did the trick.. need to test if the mesh actually works for my simulation but in paraview it looks good!
Did it like this:
[Mesh]
  [input_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = ./test_mesh.e
  []
  [wellblock]
    type = PolyLineMeshGenerator
    points = '0.2	0.5	0
    0.2	0.5	0.0777778
    0.2	0.5	0.155556
    0.2	0.5	0.233333
    0.2	0.5	0.311111
    0.2	0.5	0.388889
    0.2	0.5	0.466667
    0.2	0.5	0.544444
    0.2	0.5	0.622222
    0.2	0.5	0.7    
    '
    loop = false
  []
  [wellblockbc]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    new_boundary = 'well_block_bc'
    coord = '0.2	0.5	0;
    0.2	0.5	0.0777778;
    0.2	0.5	0.155556;
    0.2	0.5	0.233333;
    0.2	0.5	0.311111;
    0.2	0.5	0.388889;
    0.2	0.5	0.466667;
    0.2	0.5	0.544444;
    0.2	0.5	0.622222;
    0.2	0.5	0.7    
    '
    input = wellblock
  []
  [aquiferblockwithwellbc]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    new_boundary = 'well_bc_aq'
    coord = '0.2	0.5	0;
    0.2	0.5	0.0777778;
    0.2	0.5	0.155556;
    0.2	0.5	0.233333;
    0.2	0.5	0.311111;
    0.2	0.5	0.388889;
    0.2	0.5	0.466667;
    0.2	0.5	0.544444;
    0.2	0.5	0.622222;
    0.2	0.5	0.7    
    '
    input = input_mesh
  []
  [stitch]
    type = StitchedMeshGenerator
    inputs = 'aquiferblockwithwellbc wellblockbc'
    clear_stitched_boundary_ids = true
    stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'well_bc_aq well_block_bc'
  []
[]
The stitcher is verbose. Did it tell you the stitching succeeded for at least one node?

looks fine but you are stitiching all 10 nodes of the 1D mesh? So the nodeset and the 1D mesh matched exactly?
If you were just trying to create a block at a sideset location, there's this mesh generator you can use:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator.html

Jeah so I got the nodeset by extracting it from my existing mesh. I want to set a 1D mesh on the edges of my existing mesh, so yes they match exactly.
I played around with LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator but it didnt work, if I understand correctly it tries to generate a 2D block if I input a 3D mesh. And I wanted to only have the edges.
And the new block should be connected to the 3D mesh along all nodes it shares.
For more context, in a hydraulic simulation (Darcy, porous flow, GOLEM application containing the physics) the 1D block should represent a highly conductive structure (a well) that can exchange fluid flow with the surrounding 3D-mesh-elements. So if I understand it correctly the block needs be connected on all shared nodes.
Here you can see the result with a test mesh I used to figure out the workflow and how I can do this later on with a different and more complicted one:

sounds good for the simple mesh. You ll want to make sure you get physical and correct solutions on that one too (not just a working mesh) before moving to something complicated.
I think iterating on "lowerD" could have gotten you from 3D to 2D to 1D. The way you do it works
ah interesting, will try all that ! Thanks a lot for the help :)

Hey guys!
I have an additional question/situation regarding this stitching process.
Coming from a different filemesh (structured mesh based on an eclipse model using this python tool to convert it to exodus: https://github.com/cpgr/em2ex) I now get an error that says stitching is not possible due to the mesh type.
See attached the error, as well as the Mesh file and the input I use with --mesh-only to test the stitching.
Is it generally true that its not possible to add a lower 1D block to a structured 3D-hex-mesh? Are there any workarounds to this?
I somehow have to add a discrete element following an existing edge to this mesh!

MeshStitching.zip
Cheers
Florian

Hi Florian
we definitely support loading these meshes with mixed dimensional elements.
For your error right now it s complaining because you are trying to make a block with mixed element types and that s not supported
use a renameBlockGenerator before stitching to have a subdomain for each element type

Hi Guillaume,
thanks that makes sense... and I tried it but the error doesnt change unfortunately.
See my input file attached here:
Boxmodell_stiched_input.txt
if you set show_info = true in that last generator, do you get confirmation that the elements of different types are in different blocks?

ok thanks for the hints.. so I played around with show_info and looked at the renaming of my blocks with Paraview and I found that for some reason the RenameBlockGenerator behaves unexpected for my filemesh.

renaming the filemesh to a string doesnt have any effect (eg. new_block = "aquifer" --> id = 0 and name = 0)
renaming to an integer changes the id value shown by Paraview but not the name of the block
from my example input below I would expect my filemesh to be renamed to "block_21" with the id 21 but as shown in the screenshot only the id is changed not the name of the block
for the PolyLineMeshGenerator block it works as expected --> id = 4 and name = "block_4"

[input_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = ./MESH.e
[]
[rename1]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = input_mesh
    new_block = 21
    old_block = 0
[]

[wellblock]
    type = PolyLineMeshGenerator
    points = 'some coords..'
    loop = false
[]
[rename2]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = wellblock
    new_block = 4
    old_block = 0
[]

Thanks for the detailed report.
it was patched to become simpler with no need to specify name/ids but it seems there’s issues
once the rename are changing the ids, do you get a correct stitch?
yes as soon as the id values of my blocks are different stitching works! should I open an issue from this?
As you prefer. Please tag me if you do

I just discovered a bit more .. seems like my filemesh has one block without any real id ... but moose treats it as id = 0
Changing the non existing id to 0 or a string has no effect. But changing it to >0 integer applies the new id properly so its possible aftwards to change it also to a string with a second RenameBlockGenerator
So this works ... not sure if this is worth an issue since it seems to come from my filemesh.
[Mesh]
  [input_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = ./MESH.e
  []
  [rename1]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = input_mesh
    new_block = 3
    old_block = 0
  []
  [rename1_renamed]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = rename1
    new_block = 'aquifer'
    old_block = 3
  []
[]

This worked:
[Mesh]
  [input_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = ./MESH.e
  []
  [re]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = input_mesh
    old_block = '0'
    new_block = 'hhss'
  []
[]

it gave me the following:

 Mesh Subdomains:
  Subdomain 0 (hhss): 350000 elems (HEX8, 350000 active), 367236 active nodes
   Volume: 1.6e+12
   Bounding box minimum: (x,y,z)=(       0,        0,    -4000)
   Bounding box maximum: (x,y,z)=(   20000,    20000,        0)
   Bounding box delta: (x,y,z)=(   20000,    20000,     4000)
  Global mesh volume = 1.6e+12

so I dont think we've narrowed down the issue enough yet.
StitchedMG does not present block id overlap between the two parts. I m not sure we want to change that since it's easy enough to Rename normally?
jeah no need to change this!

I have a related follow up question!
The element type generated by PolyLineMeshGenerator is EDGE2. In previous meshes i used (generated externally) my well elements (1d lower dimensional block) seem to be of type TRUSS.
Cant find information on these types just that for libmesh TRUSS elements end up being treated like EDGE2:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/exodusII__io__helper_8C_source.html
But I'm wondering what the difference is between EDGE2 and TRUSS for my actual simulation? Is it something related to degrees of freedom? Where can I find more info on this?
@roystgnr will know.
@jain651 is this something you have worked on as well?

In libMesh, an ExodusII TRUSS element is just an EDGE2 with a funny birth name which is read() but then immediately changed and forgotten.
I'm not actually sure whether there's a difference to most other ExodusII codes either; at least https://github.com/sandialabs/seacas/blob/master/packages/seacas/libraries/exodus/include/exodus-element-types.md suggests that TRUSS and BAR (and TRUSS2 and BAR2) are indistinguishable to them.
In older finite element libraries you'll often see a lack of factorization of "finite element family" vs "geometric element" vs "weak form", and AFAIK that's where a lot of these naming distinctions come from.  In libMesh and MOOSE you can take e.g. an Edge2 and give it one Lagrange or Hierarchic variable for continuous Galerkin heat conduction or one Hermite variable for conduction or phase field evolution or three Lagrange variables for displacement or multi-species conduction or 6 for displacements and moments or whatever, and it's still an Edge2, but in some other codes the "element type" refers to each unique combination of geometry and discretization (including degree) and physics.

ok so if I understand correctly it shouldn't matter for any moose app?
as libmesh is only translating all synonyms to EDGE2 and there is no mechanism that limits anything on EDGE2 elements depending on their "funny birthname".

It can't matter to any app reading files only via the standard MOOSE APIs - there's not even any information retained by libMesh or MOOSE classes to tell which original name got translated to EDGE2.  MOOSE apps do have direct access to ExodusII functions, so it's not impossible for some app developer to re-open a file themselves with code that executes differently depending on what they find, but surely they wouldn't...
perfect thanks for explaining!

node.title: Extending THM FlowJunction problem
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I noticed that FlowJuction only has [FlowJunction1Phase] for single-phase flow. And the variables of VolumeJunction1Phase are {rhoV, rhouV, rhovV, rhowV, rhoEV}.
If I would like to extend this model to a two-phase flow using the six-equation model (variables are α, p, ul, ug, Tl, Tg), what the variables of VolumeJunction2Phase should be? Should it be {αl_rhol_V, αg_rhog_V, αl_rhol_ul_V, αl_rhol_vl_V, αl_rhol_wl_V, αg_rhog_ug_V, αg_rhog_vg_V, αg_rhog_wg_V, αl_rhol_El_V, αg_rhog_Eg_V}?
Thank you very much!
@joshuahansel @licharlot. I know that the existing two phase extension of THM, Relap-7, uses a 7 equation model

The choice of the variables is up to the developper for a 2 phase flow extension, but the set of variables above is the natural extension of the single phase version. Note that THM is using rhoA, rhouA and rhoEA as variables, not (p, u, T)

Thank you for your reply! Yes, the variables depend on the developer. What I would like to know is the scalar kernel of the 2-phase flow in VolumeJunction2Phase not in other regions.
Just like VolumeJunction1Phase, the scalar kernel is
, which using {rhoV, rhouV, rhovV, rhowV, rhoEV} as scalar variables.
So I think the scalar variables of 2-phase flow in VolumeJunction2Phase should be {αl_rhol_V, αg_rhog_V, αl_rhol_ul_V, αl_rhol_vl_V, αl_rhol_wl_V, αg_rhog_ug_V, αg_rhog_vg_V, αg_rhog_wg_V, αl_rhol_El_V, αg_rhog_Eg_V}.
Is that right?
Yes that's correct.
Thank you very much!

this is happening because the 'moose' Conda environment isn't active. And by reading the previous posts, your machine seems to have an issue activating these environments. What you need to do is manually edit your ~/.zshrc file and add the following to the end of it:
# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!
__conda_setup="$('/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/bin/conda' 'shell.zsh' 'hook' 2> /dev/null)"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    eval "$__conda_setup"
else
    if [ -f "/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh" ]; then
        . "/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh"
    else
        export PATH="/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup

if [ -f "/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh" ]; then
    . "/Users/johnsevic/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh"
fi
# <<< conda initialize <<<

Once you do this, close all your terminals, and start them back up. You should see a (base) prefix in your prompt. Once you do, you should then be able to activate the moose environment:
mamba activate moose
And then perform make again.

It's definitely a broken compiler.  This isn't a libMesh header; it's not even rpc.h (a POSIX standard with not-quite-standard locations).  If a "C++ compiler" fails to find the C++ standard cstdlib then it's by definition not a C++ compiler after all.
As to how it's broken... that I have no idea.  I'm a Linux person, and on any distribution with a package manager you'll have cstdlib brought in by mandatory dependencies: e.g. apt install g++ brings in g++-12 which brings in libstdc++-12-dev which installs /usr/include/c++/12/cstdlib.
On my Macbook from locate cstdlib I'm seeing versions in  /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/include/c++/v1, as well as in 4 or 5 different conda packages.  Running clang++ -E -x c++ - -v with any installed clang++ shows one of those places hard-coded into the compiler, as it's supposed to be.

node.title: Question about BreakMeshByBlock Works with Distributed Mesh
node.bodyText:
Hi all, This is a general question about CZM (breakmeshbyblock) works with distributed mesh. We currently have issues with extending our 2D CZM model into 3D due to memory constraints (limit in duplicated mesh)
I have found the following GitHub Discussion Issue page:  #12033
There is a discussion between Cody and Andrea about Pre-split mesh option to achieve distributed mesh functionality. I find it quite interesting and did a simple test in local. It seems like the interface information is saved correctly but no variables is updated at each save (as exodus file).
I wonder if this option is still in progress or it is due to my misunderstanding about the process. Thanks!
We do not currently support CZM with distributed mesh. However, #24140 aims to enable that capability
I saw some cool developments going on in #24140... Just curious about the current progress on this
I'm not sure. Maybe @ttruster can weigh in

Unfortunately I have not had free time to work on this and probably won't get to start until December 2023 at the earliest. It is still one of my goals; currently (back in May 2023) the implementation runs, but now error cases need to be handled.
I am also open to mentoring someone else on wrapping this up if there is an interest/need to have it sooner.

node.title: PorousFlow Basic question on BCs
node.bodyText:
Hi,
In my TH model, I fix the temperature at the boundaries and set a zero-pressure condition at the top of the model. I would expect a pressure profile given by -rho * g * y, but it looks like the solution found in steady state is slightly different. Why is that? Perhaps there is some physics I am missing? (see temp_grav_test_s.i)
Then, I modify the BCs to have flux from left to right with Dirichlet BCs. The temperature is fixed at the left, and 'PorousFlowOutflowBC' at the right allows free outflow of temperature. It seems to work fine for pore pressure, but the temperature diverges. Note that this works fine without gravity. Why is that? (see temp_grav_test.i)
Finally, I would like to implement 'PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink' to model flow and temperature instead of Dirichlet BCs. How can I set up these boundaries in the case of temperature? Something like this, maybe?
  [in_left]
    type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink
    variable = porepressure
    boundary = 'left'
    pt_vals = '-1e9 1e9' # x coordinates defining g
    multipliers = '-1e9 1e9' # y coordinates defining g
    PT_shift = 2.E6   # BC pressure
    flux_function = 1E-5 # Variable C
    fluid_phase = 0
  []

  [in_left_temp]
    type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink
    variable = temperature
    boundary = 'left'
    pt_vals = '-1e9 1e9' # x coordinates defining g
    multipliers = '-1e9 1e9' # y coordinates defining g
    PT_shift = 280   # BC temperature
    flux_function = 1E-5 # Variable C
    fluid_phase = 0
  []

To the models: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1KY9KZ558KDBJsSsjcUQEHvs1R0v5FTed?usp=drive_link
Edit:
Link to the github repos: https://github.com/burritotukituki/PorousFlowStuff
Many thanks in advance!
Tukituki

Hello
The google drive seems to have restricted access. We'd prefer a github repo in general to host input files.
Did you specify a gravity term?
Guillaume

Hi,
Thanks I added a github repo. Yes, I specify gravity ;).
I cant see it. Not sure if it s morning-me though haha

Here
https://github.com/burritotukituki/PorousFlowStuff/blob/main/temp_grav_test.i
and here
https://github.com/burritotukituki/PorousFlowStuff/blob/main/temp_grav_test_s.i
I dont see what could be wrong. @cpgr mind taking a look

I wonder, if you considered that SimpleFluidProperties calculates fluid density as a function of pressure and temperature? The given density0 is just the reference density and gets updated during solution.
So your result of '-rho * g * y' has to assume the correct density as function of y.
This is the most likely cause - you can set the thermal expansion to 0 and make the bulk modulus really big to try and mimic a constant density

Looks like @WilkAndy is an expert on this field. Can you please give me a hint on this?
Cheers!
Hi @cpgr, can you please also help in in this issue?

node.title: PorousFlow - Heat injection in wells
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have a TH system in which water is injected and recovered through various wells at different locations within the model. In my current simulation setup, I am utilizing the PorousFlowPolyLineSink method to control fluid flux rather. Specifically, I have employed PorousFlowPolyLineSink for managing pore pressure, while I have imposed fixed Dirichlet boundary conditions for temperature. I am seeking your advice on whether this is the most appropriate approach.
However, I have encountered an issue when attempting to implement PorousFlowPolyLineSink in conjunction with temperature. It appears that my simulation diverges in this configuration, as exemplified below:
  [DiracKernels]  
  [heat_in]
        type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
        SumQuantityUO = source_hot_heat
        fluxes = -1
        p_or_t_vals = 0.0
        line_length = 10.0
        multiplying_var = temp
        use_enthalpy = true
        point_file = inj.bh
        variable = temperature
    []
[]

  [AuxVariables]
    [temp]
      initial_condition = 293
    []
[]

Any suggestions of how can I set this polyline?
Is it just because you have a zero value for p_or_t_vals so it is trying to inject 0 heat?

@cpgr
It doesnt matter what value I set there, still injects cold fluid...
I am bit confused, in this example (modules/combined/examples/geochem-porous_flow/geotes_2D/porous_flow.i) every 'p_or_t_vals' is set to zero.
Can you please check this minimal example and let me know what am I doing wrong? Many thanks :)
https://github.com/burritotukituki/PorousFlowStuff/blob/main/min_chris.i
Thanks!!
OK, that's not it then! Can you post your inj.bh file too?

Sure, many thanks!!

https://github.com/burritotukituki/PorousFlowStuff/blob/main/inj.bh

I write just to reaming you about this issue :)

node.title: How to use time derivative of variable in kernel?

node.bodyText:
you have dot_u in the code here not u_dot
_u_dot[_qp] is defined at the kernel base class level
but if you are using AD maybe you want  _ad_u_dot instead
Guillaume

I have just given _ad_u_dot[_qp] a go, but I am still getting this error:
sc_res/src/kernels/eq66Re.C:55:27: error: '_ad_u_dot' was not declared in this scope; did you mean '_ad_q_point'?

not declared then
add it to your header
 ADVariableValue _ad_u_dot

and in your constructor in the source
... <rest of constructor initialization list> ,
_ad_u_dot(adCoupledDot("u")

Ah that seems to of worked thank you!
Why do you need to add _u_dot to the header but not _grad_u out of interest?

so actually this is probably part of the problem.
We do not have to add _u_dot when we are in the right class of kernels.
Usually we want time derivative terms to inherit from TimeKernels so that they play well with the time integration scheme and contribute to the right part of the matrix
so I m thinking you ll need to split that time derivative term into a separate kernel that inherit from time kernels

Ah ok! Thank you for the help Guillaume!
Ill let you know if I encounter any more issues!

call it 'variable' maybe instead of u
or whatever its name in the parameters currently is

I have changed _ad_u_dot(adCoupledDot("u")) to _ad_u_dot(adCoupledDot("Psi_Re"))
That seems to give the error :
*** ERROR ***
eq66Re: The coupled variable "Psi_Re" was never added to this object's InputParameters, please double-check your spelling

This is where it is called in the .i file:
[Kernels]
    [eq66Re]
      type = eq66Re
      variable = Psi_Re
      Psi_Im = Psi_Im
      Phi = Phi
      ucon = ucon
      gamma = gamma
    []
[]
you ll need to add the variable as a coupledVar (with params.addCoupledVar) instead of just a variable name

node.title: Stitched Mesh with nodes not at the exact same locations.
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am using the StitchedMeshGenerator to connect two distinct mesh together.
It seems that this functionality only merges nodes that are at the exact same geometric location.
Does anyone knows if it possible to merge nodes from the stitch_boundaries_pairs that are not exactly at the same location; e.g. using a maximum distance parameter ?
Cordially
Fred

Hello
the MeshRepairGenerato will let you merge overlapping nodes with a tolerance that you can set to be big if you want
at your own risk though
Merci Guillaume, I had missed this functionality but will try in now.

Hi,
I have tried the MeshRepairGenerator and it works very well on my simple model; but I can see that it can be tricky in some cases as it applies to the whole mesh.
Thanks again.
Fred

node.title: Contact Distance Parameter
node.bodyText: I am working a problem with thermal expansion between two bodies with a small initial gap (1E-4). Based on hand calculations and other FE solvers the two bodies will not come into contact but have a very small gap (1E-5), but with the MOOSE simulation the bodies do in fact come in to contact and at a lower heat input. Is there a parameter I am missing in the contact action block that controls the nodal distance when checking for contact?

Hello
Is your result in MOOSE converged?
In terms of:

mesh density
time grid size
nonlinear residuals

Guillaume

looks like you can play with detection of contact pairs to prevent contact from being detected with automatic_pairing_distance
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Contact/index.html

I am able to get a converged solution in MOOSE.
From the link you provided, my understanding is that is for automatic pairing correct? I would need to not use the primary and secondary keys but instead provide the surfaces in the auto pairing and let MOOSE figure it out that way?

I think so
@recuero will know on setting contact parameters

Is there a parameter I am missing in the contact action block that controls the nodal distance when checking for contact?

If the bodies come into contact, and you expect them not to be, I wouldn't look into contact or contact parameters. My suggestion: Remove contact and analyze your setup and model parameters so that they match the expected thermal expansion behavior.

I can give that another try on the higher heat input case. My initial thought on looking at the contact parameters is because with a lower heat input case (the rest of the input file remaining the same), the thermal expansion lines up with hand calcs.  In that version of the problem the expected gap is still on the E-4 range so my initial thought was that at E-5 I was running up a tolerance somewhere.
I will rerun both cases without contact.

at E-5 I was running up a tolerance somewhere

There is no default parameter or behavior that would cause that. That could maybe happen if you are using contact constraints and your tolerances are very loose, but it's rare, that's why I'd double check the results without contact. Also, if you output the mesh on a visualization software, you should be able to see if there is contact.

I am still running the cases without contact. The lower heat input case can solve quickly, but the higher heat input seems to be having issues finishing the solve requiring me to ramp up the BC. I am able to get to about 80% of the final heat input before the simulation slows down and requires really small timesteps to continue through. From the output so far, it appears that the expansion and temperatures are lining up well with my hand calcs.

If I understand well, when you run this simulation you last mentioned the bodies do not come into contact. But in the statement of the problem at the top you mention they do come into contact: Do you have an image that shows this?

I have a lower heat input that does not come into contact and a higher that still shouldn't come into contact. This is based on hand calcs and running in Ansys. For my higher heat input the bodies do come into contact.
I have attached 3 images. The simulation at the beginning, the end and the contact pressure plot. All for the higher heat input case. I am also using a postprocessor to output the displacements on the OD of the inner cylinder and the ID of the outer cylinder. These relative displacements also show the gap is closed.
You have negative contact pressure?
Yes, that also does not make much sense to me. But since they weren't supposed to be in contact anyway, I figured I would start with that problem first. Unless you think they are related?

Contact doesn't "attract" surfaces, so I am still confused as to why you might be getting contact (zero gap) only when you include the contact action. It seems that your simulation without contact didn't finish; I'd first make sure that, with that single change, i.e. removing the contact action, you don't get the zero gap result.
You can attach your input file and I can take a quick look.

Yeah, I will let you know when the non-contact run finishes.
I have attached the input file associated with the images previously. The only change other than the contact vs non-contact between what is running now and this is that I am building the mesh within moose right now so I can more easily play with the mesh density rather than going back and forth with cubit.
closed_gap_contact_hex20.zip

It does not appear that the thermal expansion case is going to finish....or at least in a reasonable amount of time. It went to about 85% of the required input before slashing the time steps/ramping on the heat input. At about 4 hours now and its sitting at 91% and taking E-8 time steps. The lower heat (an order of magnitude less) was less than 5 minutes.
As of right now in the simulation based on the displacement values, the bodies are not in contact which is an improvement since I believe when I ran the contact solution they were already in contact at this point.
I have tried running a thermal only solution at the expected final gap number and it seems to line up well with hand calcs as well. So is there something wrong with my expansion inputs? I would imagine if they were really wrong the other solution wouldn't work at all, but maybe I need to adjust something due to the amount of expansion?
